_exec_summary.SummaryText:
ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION AND EMERGENCY RELEASE POLICIES

The MPLX LLC Brecksville LP Terminal is a refined petroleum product distributor. The Brecksville LP Terminal is an on-shore, light products, bulk petroleum storage terminal used in the storage and distribution of petroleum products to retail and commercial end-users in the vicinity of Brecksville, OH. The Terminal handles and stores various grades of unleaded gasoline, low sulfur diesel/#2 fuel oil, butane, ethanol, and various other petroleum-based additives.

Brecksville LP Terminal is committed to operating and maintaining processes in a safe, reliable and environmentally sound manner. MPLX believes that excellent performance in health, safety, and the environment goes hand in hand with operating reliably, and that outstanding HES performance is of paramount importance.

The Terminal is designed, operated and maintained in a manner that protects the environment, as well as the health and safety of its employees, contractors and the community. MPLX promotes health, safety, and the environment through programs of awareness, compliance, prevention and protection. These programs include a combination of accidental release prevention and emergency response planning. This summary provides a brief overview of the comprehensive risk management activities that MPLX has designed and implemented, including:

A. A description of the facility and the use of regulated substances;
B. An overview of the accidental release prevention programs;
C. A five-year, RMP-reportable accident history for accidental releases of regulated chemicals;
D. An overview of the emergency response program; and
E. An overview of planned changes to improve safety.

A. STATIONARY SOURCE AND REGULATED SUBSTANCES

The Brecksville LP Terminal butane tank blending process has been classified as Program Level 3. No Program 1 or 2 processes containing regulated substances were identified. By virtue of its flammable effects, it is necessary to obse

or employees;
-Communication systems with local emergency responders and regulatory agencies; and
-Emergency drills with Terminal personnel, regulatory agencies, and community emergency responders to enhance response skills and coordination among agencies.

Further, the Brecksville LP Terminal complies with the National Fire Protection Association's (NFPA's) Liquefied Petroleum Gas (LPG) Code (NFPA-58) requirements. In addition to the presence of appropriate controls to prevent possible releases of butane, a Emergency Response Action Plan (ERAP)/"Smart Plan" is in place for the Facility with response activities coordinated with Richfield Fire Department/Brecksville Fire Department.

C. FIVE YEAR ACCIDENT HISTORY

The Brecksville LP Terminal has an excellent record of accident prevention. The Terminal maintains records for all incidental and significant chemical releases inclusive of any root cause analyses and associated, follow-up actions. There have been no RMP-reportable accidents within the past five (5) years.

D. EMERGENCY RESPONSE PROGRAM

The Facility is identified as a "Non-Responding" facility with its emergency response plans being coordinated with the Richfield Fire Department/Brecksville Fire Department and Cuyahoga County Office of Emergency Management.  

In the event of an emergency involving the Brecksville LP Terminal butane tank blending system, it is the policy of the Terminal to initially contact the Richfield Fire Department/Brecksville Fire Department and request their assistance. The Facility maintains incipient fire response and HAZWOPER 1st Responder Operations capabilities.

The Richfield Fire Department/Brecksville Fire Department participates in annual butane training/coordination sessions for this system.

E. PLANNED CHANGES TO IMPROVE SAFETY

MPLX is continually striving to make the Brecksville LP Terminal the safest and most reliable workplace possible for its employees, neighbors and community.

In an effort to improve and promote sy

stem safety, MPLX actively seeks employee input on process safety improvements. All Process Safety Events (as identified in API 754) are electronically recorded, reviewed, and/or investigated via a root cause analysis (TapRooT) per MPC policy.  The Terminal continuously reviews applicable codes retro-active requirements and process safety improvements.
